titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers MSS.321
titlestmt.author: Colin Torre

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-03-11 08:48:27 -0500.

change.item: Updated by Jasmine Larkin to include unprocessed publications, ephemera, and project files from accession number 2011.321, and edited for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description.

did.unittitle: John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers

physdesc.extent: in 3 records cartons, 5 flat boxes, 4 manuscript boxes, 2 oversize flat boxes, 2 flat file folders, and 1 half manuscript box.

did.abstract: John Vaccaro is an actor and theatrical director who became a primary figure of the Off-Off Broadway and gay theater communities in New York City. The John Vaccaro Papers preserve the items related to Vaccaro's theatrical productions, including scripts, correspondence, photographs, posters and critical notices. Materials date from 1959 to 2005.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: Materials primarily in English, with some publications in French, German, Italian, and Dutch.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by John Vaccaro, 2011. The accession number associated with this gift is 2011.321.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into 4 series. Oversize materials are listed at the end of the finding aid.

list.item: Oversize - Series II: Posters and Ephemera

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John Vaccaro was born in Steubenville, Ohio on December 6, 1929. After serving in the U.S. Navy from 1951-1955, and receiving a B.A. in English from Ohio State University in 1961, he moved to New York City and became involved in the underground art and film community of the early sixties. After acting in Jack Smith's Normal Love and Flaming Creatures, and performing in the "Happenings" of Robert Whitman and Walter DeMaria, Vaccaro founded the Play-House of the Ridiculous in the summer of 1965. Early collaborators and playwrights in this community included Ronald Tavel, Charles Ludlam and Kenneth Bernard. In 1967, during preparatory work for a production of Ludlam's play Conquest of the Universe, or When Queens Collide Vaccaro and Ludlam came to a disagreement and split into competing companies (Vaccaro retained the Play-House of the Ridiculous; Ludlam founded the Ridiculous Theatrical Company).

Vaccaro's productions were staged at the Coda Gallery, La Mama ETC, the Gotham Art Theater, Max's Kansas City, The American Place Theater, and other Off-Broadway and Off-Off-Broadway venues in New York. In 1970 Vaccaro received a special citation OBIE award. While sometimes performing in and writing the music for his own productions, Vaccaro took his companies on tours of Europe throughout the 1970s and served as director of the Native American Theatrical Ensemble. His theatrical influences include Alfred Jarry, Amiri Baraka, Eugene Ionesco, Charlie Chaplin, Antonin Artaud, and Jack Smith. In addition to the non-professional actors often employed in his productions, Vaccaro is associated with a variety of figures from the New York art and theater worlds, including Taylor Mead, Beverly Grant, Mary Woronov, Rene Ricard, Rosalyn Drexler, Ultra Violet, and Richard Weinstock. Vaccaro has lectured at a number universities and workshops, and has directed performances of his productions for the BBC and Dutch television.
"Life of Juanita Castro" by Ronald Tavel (1965)
"The Life of Lady Godiva" by Ronald Tavel (1966)
"Screen Test"/"Indira Gandhi's Daring Device" both by Ronald Tavel (1966)
"Conquest of the Universe" by Charles Ludlam (1967)
"Monkeys of the Organ Grinder" by Kenneth Bernard (1969)
"Heaven Grand In Amber Orbit" by Jackie Curtis (1969)
"Son of Cock Strong" by Tom Murrin (1970)
"Life of Lady Godiva" by Ronald Tavel (1971)
"The Life of Juanita Castro" by Ronald Tavel (1971)
"Persia, A Desert Cheapie" by Bernard Roth & Vaccaro (1972)
"Elegy for a Down Queen" by Leslie Lee (1973)
"The Magic Show of Dr. Magico" by Kenneth Bernard (1973-1974)
"Workshop of Y.M.C.A." by Gerome Ragni & James Rado (1975-1976)
"The Sixty Minute Queer Show" by Kenneth Bernard (1977)
"The Book of Etiquette" by William M. Hoffman (1979)
"A Midsummer Night's Dream" by William Shakespeare (1980)
"La Fin du Cirque" by Kenneth Bernard (1984)
"The Heart That Eats Itself" by Rosalyn Drexler (1987)

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers; MSS 321; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing decisions made prior to September 2018 have not been recorded.
In September 2018, unprocessed publications, ephemera, and project files were housed in archival folders and boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers contain materials that document Vaccaro's professional theatrical career, ranging from the early 1960s through 2005. The collection preserves Vaccaro's primarily collaborative work, including scripts, notebooks, articles, essays, and correspondence that date back to his early career as an actor in the emerging world of Off-Off Broadway theater in New York. Elements include source material for his productions as well as promotional material in the form of ephemera, flyers, festival programs, posters and postcards. This body of components also includes the work of collaborating playwrights, and material related to the theatrical and Greenwich Village communities of the 1960s, 70s and 80s. In addition, this collection includes professional and personal correspondence, production and personal photography, original illustrations, publications, and a scrapbook. Materials date from 1959 to 2005.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by John Vaccaro was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

physdesc.extent: in 2 record cartons, 1 manuscript box, and 1 half manuscript box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I: Projects contains the work of John Vaccaro and others. Materials inculde press clippings, screenplays, contracts, and ephemera generally related to the titular project. Materials date from 1959 to 1992.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I: Projects is organized alphabetically by project title.

did.unittitle: The Heart That Eats Itself Script
The Sixty Minute Queer Show Script
"Songs from Cockstrong, Heaven Grand, Son of Cockstrong"
"Three Plays at New Theatre by K. Bernard"

physdesc.extent: in 3 flat boxes and 1 half manuscript box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II: Posters and Ephemera contains posters, publicity material, objects, and a scrapbook. All the materials relate to Vaccaro's theatrical productions and his work with with the Play-House of the Ridiculous. Materials date from 1981 to 2005.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II: Posters and Ephemera is organized alphabetically by production title or the name of the institution.

did.unittitle: A Matter of Life and Death
Play-House of the Ridiculous Repertory Club Membership Cards

physdesc.extent: in 2 manuscript boxes and 2 flat boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III: Photographs contains photographs, contact sheets, negatives, and slides pertaining to Vaccaro's productions and personal collection. Most of the people and plays in the photographs in the collection are unidentified at this time. Materials are undated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III: Photographs has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from Vaccaro.

did.unittitle: Fred Ohrenstein Photo of John Vaccaro

physdesc.extent: in 1 record carton, 1 manuscript box, 1 half manuscript box, and 1 flat box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV: Publications contains monographs, exhibition catalogs, journals, and magazines. The publications were collected by John Vaccaro and are related to theater and music. Some of the publications contain articles about Vaccarro and his work. Materials date from 1964 to 2005. Most of the publications are in English, with a few in French, German, Italian, and Dutch.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV: Publications has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize Series I: Projects contains oversize material related to theatrical productions. Materials date from 1966 to 1985.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Oversize Series I: Projects is arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Oversize - Series II: Posters and Ephemera

physdesc.extent: in 2 oversize flat boxes and 2 flat file folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize Series II: Posters and Ephemera contains posters and publicity material related to Vaccaro's theatrical productions. Materials date from 1961 to 1979.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Oversize Series II: Posters and Ephemera is arranged alphabetically.
